content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser : anything to share?
  • WG-llvm by @nagisa: anything to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; triage meeting starts now! add a :wave: to show you're here!

we'll start off with a few minutes for

Announcements
• Today new stable release 1.58 is out :loudspeaker: :tada:
• Tomorrow at 2022-01-14T10:00:00-05:00 Planning meeting
no that's not right
fixed
oh the time. thanks

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).

MCPs/FCPs

  • New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 6 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: about 34 days ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: about 34 days ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: about 17 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize -Z instrument-coverage as -C instrument-coverage" rust#90132
    • "Stabilize -Z print-link-args as --print link-args" rust#91606

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439
    • "Adding known bugs to test cases" compiler-team#476
    • "Introduce a new linter for diagnostic meesages" compiler-team#478

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Remove effect of #[no_link] attribute on name resolution" rust#92034
WG checkins

-Z instrument-coverage needs 3 more people to sign off and -Z print-link-args needs one more. Please take a look if you haven't checked your box yet or leave a concern if we're missing something! :smile:

WG checkins

  • wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser (previous checkin)
@Wesley Wiser correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think we have anything to report since last checkin?
We've had a bunch of fixes and improvements land recently from @Aaron Hill and @cjgillot which is great to see!
But the wg has been pretty dormant.
It would be great to get that running again this year!
• WG-llvm by @nagisa (previous checkin)
We can let @nagisa post the @WG-llvm update asynchronously

so we can move on to

Backport nominations
T-compiler beta / T-compiler stable
• No backport nominations for T-compiler this time.
(Always nice to see that on release week)

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Fix ICE with inferred type in const or static item" rust#89161 (last activity: 3 months ago)
    • waiting on @nikomatsakis (or perhaps reassign as he pointed out not being too familiar with the code)
I will take this. @nikomatsakis and I have a standing meeting dedicated to reviews, so in the worst case I'll pester him about it.

• "Fix variant index / discriminant confusion in uninhabited enum branching" rust#89764 (last activity: 2 months ago)
    • opened by @tm
    • assigned to @Wesley Wiser, last comment
    • Seems some concerns were addressed by rust#91095 and rust#91088?
    • is s-waiting-on-review the current status?
Yeah, I think this is just waiting on me to review & sign off.
My review queue got pretty large over the holidays so I'm working on getting it under control.
I'm trying to skim the PR comments
were the semantic questions satisified?
No and it looks like the corresponding miri changes were also reverted.
okay. I guess it sounds like there are still open questions here, but the right stakeholders are engaged ...
so i'll leave that in its existing state

• "Closure capture cleanup & refactor" rust#89861 (opened 3 months ago)
    • assigned to @Wesley Wiser

I need to reread the thread but I think we probably still want to land this since we currently have a bug in this MIR pass which the PR resolves but there's a question if we want this MIR pass at all (but that seems orthogonal to the PR).
I just reviewed that this morning. :smile:
great

• "Improve terminology around 'after typeck'" rust#90277 (last activity: 1 month ago)
    • assigned to @eddyb
    • pr author left some comments for review
@eddyb if you need this reassigned to someone else, let us know.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 3 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 78 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 52 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 0 P-high, 0 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 3 P-critical, 51 P-high, 81 P-medium, 12 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable
It might be good for us to try to burn down that stack of P-high issues
not sure how best to drive an initiative there

pnkfelix said:

  • "Improve terminology around 'after typeck'" rust#90277 (last activity: 1 month ago)
    • assigned to eddyb
    • pr author left some comments for review

I don't recall ever seeing this before. I removed myself from review rotation a while back, despite my best efforts I haven't been able to engage with it much - I guess in this case it was a manual r?
yes I think it was a manual r?
we can reassign
Yes, because it was your FIXME
I can take this
thanks!

before you offered, I was gonna suggest in general, that someone with some knowledge of type inference should pick it up (especially any new infra that I'm less familiar with, like MIR borrowck and Chalk interactions)
on with P-critical bug checkin

P-critical

T-compiler
It seems pretty straightforward; just rewording

• "Miscompilation where binding only some fields leaks the others" rust#90752
    • addressed by rustc#90788 -> out in 1.58

• "Compile-time regression between 1.56.1 and 1.57.0 for deeply nested decorator types" rust#91598
    • addressed by rustc#90423 -> out in 1.58

• "no MIR available for DefId" rust#92755
    • @Lambinoo is working on a fix (rust#92781)

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2022-01-12

Improvements generally outweighed regressions with most regressions coming in the form of correctness fixes (where performance regressions are generally less of a concern). The biggest win was arguably a change to the Sip128 hasher implementation which seemed to have decent performance implications for many real world crates.

Triage done by @rylev.
Revision range: 2b681ac06b1a6b7ea39525e59363ffee0d1a68e5..72e74d7b9cf1a7901650227e74650f1fcc797600

3 Regressions, 7 Improvements, 2 Mixed; 4 of them in rollups
28 comparisons made in total
28 Untriaged Pull Requests

Regressions

Hash Ident spans in all HIR structures #92534

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 1.6% on incr-unchanged builds of derive)
  • A subset of of #92210 which has absolutely horrific performance regressions. This is a partial fix where the regressions are much less severe.
  • This is a correctness fix so performance loss is typically much more acceptable. Without this fix, it was possible for incremental compilation to be broken when a change to a span was misidentified as not being an actual change.

Ensure that Fingerprint caching respects hashing configuration #92278

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.3% on incr-unchanged builds of clap-rs)
  • Another fix in how we're doing hashing of certain structures. This is a correctness fix and as such, the relatively moderation regression was deemed acceptable.

Actually instantiate the opaque type when checking bounds #90948

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.2% on full builds of wg-grammar)
  • The regressions are mostly limited to a stress benchmark (wg-grammar) and as a correctness fix were deemed acceptable.

Improvements

  • Do not hash leading zero bytes of i64 numbers in Sip128 hasher #92103
  • Rollup of 8 pull requests #92627
  • rustc_metadata: Optimize and document module children decoding #92086
  • Rollup of 8 pull requests #92690
  • Fixes wrong unreachable_pub lints on nested and glob public reexport #87487
  • Rollup of 7 pull requests #92719
  • Store a Symbol instead of an Ident in VariantDef/FieldDef #92533
Not entirely surprised that there were several rollups with perf effects. Queue has been long
yeah I was just reflecting on that
more about how I'd like to celebrate the specific PRs that improved things. :)

Mixed

Rollup of 7 pull requests #92556

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.6% on incr-full builds of issue-88862)
  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 6.6% on full builds of tokio-webpush-simple)

Switch all libraries to the 2021 edition #92068

  • Small improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.4% on full builds of cranelift-codegen)
  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 3.1% on incr-patched: b9b3e592dd cherry picked builds of style-servo)
  • Seems like the panic infrastructure in the 2021 edition is ever so slightly more expensive to compile and run causing this issue. It was deemed acceptable to take the small performance hit.
i do wonder what caused the perf changes in PR #92556
revert #92254 "Bump gsgdt to 0.1.3" #92532 maybe?
oh maybe
is gsgdt performance sensitive?
well the timings here are compile times, right? So the behavior of gsgdt doesn't matter?
or no, I'm confusing myself
gsgdt is a "opinionated graph visualization and graph diff visualization library", so I'm assuming its never part of the compiler's critical path
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/91884 constifies Box methods, which might lead to more constant evaluation?
The PR that originally bumped gsgdt seems pretty neutral https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/92254#issuecomment-1002598248
yeah i'm going to guess PR #91884 for now
anyway we've made great progress on the agenda, we can actually spend time on the nominated topics

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "sess: default to v0 symbol mangling" rust#89917
    • update: stabilize -Z symbol-mangling-version=v0 as -C symbol-mangling-version=v0 in rust#90128 (merged 10 days ago)
wait this has been nominated for months
how come i don't remember it on previous agendas?
(a mistake in previous agenda constructions?)
yes from time to time I put it back, when there is something new about it
I'm pretty sure we talked about this a while ago. It was nominated in October.
oh i see okay
we can probably un-nominate it for now
i should probably backlink prev. discussions
the tracking issue, #60705, says that there is progress made on the gcc/liberty/valgrind side, see this comment
IIRC, the nomination was about making the new mangling scheme the default on nightly (and only there) to get more feedback
but since then we have made it the default for the compiler itself, and have gotten feedback that way
heh
We should be considering updating our documentation to permit the .llvm suffixes (i.e., the RFC), though, right?
(I don't think anyone is owning that)

simulacrum said:

We should be considering updating our documentation to permit the .llvm suffixes (i.e., the RFC), though, right?

Yeah, I've been planning to make a PR for weeks but never got to it :/
Vadim Petrochenkov suggested that as well here https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/247081-t-compiler.2Fperformance/topic/Noise.20in.20symbol.20names/near/266233420
I assume that the main blocker for making this the default is support in tools elsewhere like valgrind, does that sound right?
Yes, and updating the default behavior of rustc_demangle to generate less verbose output (IMO)
okay

What kind of stability guarantees do we have around the v0 scheme? Are we still allowed to make these kinds of changes? Do we need to make sure that change goes in before -C symbol-mangling=v0 reaches stable?
The RFC does not define what unmangled names look like, so that should be fine
"that change" meaning the change to rustc_demangle ?
I was mainly referring to the .llvm suffixes change.
for the vendor-specific suffix, that should be backwards compatible and basically already is implemented that way
but it can't hurt to update the grammar in the RFC asap
does anybody want to own making a PR? otherwise I'll do it within the next few days
Zulip really needs a tumbleweed emoji :)
@mw I'll do it
sounds great everyone
only one thing left on agenda

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
so with that, unless @nagisa has anything to discuss w.r.t. WG-llvm, I think we can wrap this up.
@lqd awesome!

thanks for everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! Just a reminder: We've got a planning meeting tomorrow. If you have any steering meeting ideas to propose, throw them up before 2022-01-14T10:00:00-05:00 tomorrow!

one question while we're all here:

pnkfelix said:

It might be good for us to try to burn down that stack of P-high issues

w.r.t. to these unassigned issues: would it help if a grab a small amount of them (~5) at every t-compiler mtg? or would that be too much on the table for the meeting?
Off topic but just wanted to highlight some work @Arlo Siemsen has done to get a proper identifier for Rust in the Windows pdb format. PR for anyone interested

apiraino said:

one question while we're all here:

pnkfelix said:

It might be good for us to try to burn down that stack of P-high issues

w.r.t. to these unassigned issues: would it help if a grab a small amount of them (~5) at every t-compiler mtg? or would that be too much on the table for the meeting?

I'm not sure. I think we might need a dedicated sprint or something.
I wonder if we should schedule a Friday meeting (or meetings) to run through that list.
yeah I was just musing about that.
I might as well throw it up as a proposal for tomorrowl
Oh, is tomorrow the scheduling meeting?
/me checks calendar

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/PPMtXP7hSqmyqD30CUw_cQ?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-mir-opt by @oli
  • @_WG-polymorphization_ checkin by @davidtwco

I don't have much to share about WG-llvm happenings. The deferred inlining work is probably the highlight since the last check-in. But we're also seeing some fixes going upstream for debug info (e.g. codeview should now know its looking at Rust) and stack probing (CFI information fixes). Basucally business as usual.
